body:
@kishoreg  ideally we need as many locks as number of realtime tables. Curently, we hash a table name to a lock and acquire the lock before updating idealstate. The locks are so that we don't have conflicts on updating idealstate. We had seen the conflicts before, and introduced lock (which did much better than conflict and backoff-retry).
The symptom that need us to increase the number of locks (from hard-coded 4 to a default 64) was that several new use cases have been added that have 40+ partitions (often times lazy, with hardly any events). These resulted in lot more collisions across tables. So, many realtime hosts started experiencing issues sending segmentConsumed() message to the lead controller (timeout). We root-caused the wait to a wait on this lock, and want to increase it from its current value of 4.
Since the issue hasn't reproduced recently, I think we should keep the sys.out.printlns to aid debugging when it happens next and merge the change.

Correct, and that was my proposal to @jamesyfshao  as well (to evaluate and emit the metric at the time we commit, on the server rather than controller).

I am just not sure what the evaluated metric would be, though.

Since we are moving in the direction of a generic stream, I would want this evaluation to be done inside the specific consumer code.

@jamesyfshao  can you elaborate further on how you are planning to compute the metric?

Another idea (like you mentioned) is to monitor using external Kafka monitoring services. That worked well for us, and you may want to look into  it.

Also, you should strongly consider moving to LLC.

@mcvsubbu @kishoreg  the lag I referred above is the difference between the latest offset(high-water mark) of a particular kafka input topic partition and the consumer last committed offset for that topic. There are multiple scenarios that lag might increase:

1. kafka input topic has surge in traffic and pinot consumer is not able to catch up, causing the lag to increase
2. misconfig/bugs in a particular pinot server caused it to slow down or stuck and not able to catch up with kafka input topic
3. bug in kafka consumers that cause reset offset to an earlier offset.

If we have a pinot component that can help us to calculate the lag between the latest available offset for each partition and our consumer last committed offset and emit this information to pinot Metrics, pinot users would be able to set up alerts based on this "lag" number, either based on per-partition lag value or aggregated lag value. The scenarios we mentioned above would be captured easily.

I would say putting such calculation in kafka consumer within pinot server would also be a great way to do it. The only problem is that it will not be able to catch scenario No.2 I listed above. However, it is a really uncommon issue and we could ignore it for now.

For using external Kafka monitoring service, it would be great if it is already available within users' infrastructure but it is an external dependency that we will require pinot users to set up and operate. I feel like it would be better if we could provide users means to achieve the same goal without setting up such external dependency. Also adding/removing consumer group to monitor (for HLC at least) when we add/remove pinot table is tricky to automated with external monitor services (with the reason I mentioned above).

If it sounds good, we will spend more time investigating implementing such metrics calculation logics within kafka consumer

> @jamesyfshao can we compute the offset in the controller without contacting individual servers?

It is possible to compute offset in controller (at least for hlc consumer) as pinot store the information about consumer group id, partition under property store zk node.

Example zknode content about this info:

```
$ zkcli get <parent zk node>/PROPERTYSTORE/CONFIGS/INSTANCE/<server_node>

('{\n  "id":"<server node>"\n  ,"simpleFields":{\n  }\n  ,"listFields":{\n  }\n  ,"mapFields":{\n    "KAFKA_HLC_GROUP_MAP":{\n      "<realtime table name>":"<consumer group id>"\n      ....    }\n    ,"KAFKA_HLC_PARTITION_MAP":{\n      "<realtime table name>":"<partition id>"\n          }\n  }\n}', ZnodeStat(...))
```

table config about zookeeper and topic name can be retrieved in zookeeper node  `<parent node>/PROPERTYSTORE/CONFIGS/TABLE/<table name>`.

Pinot controller should have access to those info. for example, class `PinotRealtimeSegmentManager` has access to groupid/partition-id through **`_pinotHelixResourceManager.getInstanceZKMetadata(instanceId)`** and table info through `HelixInstanceDataManager`. But I have to admit it is a fairly early investigation and we have not looked into llc cases and other streaming solutions. We will definitely do more investigation once we have more ideas about which direction we want to focus on
Linking to https://github.com/linkedin/pinot/issues/2583

Pinot controller only has info on the group ID.

It does not have info on offset up to which each partition has consumed. Neither does it have info on what the offset is in Kafka. Since we use Kafka's commit code, this info is stored by Kafka in whatever format they seem fit in some location unknown to Pinot. I would not want Pinot to be dependent on this format or location (which may change across Kafka versions, we don't know).

It seems to me that any which way you try to get these two pieces of information, it will be a re-write of the tools that Kafka may provide, to compute offset lag. Have you looked at any Kafka tools, and tried to use them?

Like I mentioned before, LLC already has the problem solved, so have you considered moving to LLC?
